Admission Date:  [**2162-12-28**]     Discharge Date:  [**2163-1-1**]

Date of Birth:   [**2140-5-22**]     Sex:  M

Service:  Transplant Surgery

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Motor vehicle crash.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 22-year-old
gentleman involved in a high-speed motor vehicle crash with
positive loss of consciousness at the scene.  The patient had
[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 2611**] Coma Scale of 3 at the scene and was intubated by
emergency personnel.

The patient was transferred via Life Flight to the [**Hospital1 1444**] with bradycardia and
hypertension.  The patient had a positive left lower
extremity deformity with external rotation of the leg and
shortening.  The patient did have a prolonged extrication
time of over 15 minutes, during which a presumed anoxic
injury occurred.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  None.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Previous facial reconstruction after
a traumatic event during a baseball game.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:  None.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  No alcohol.  No smoking.  No recreational
drugs (per the family).

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON PRESENTATION:  Initial vital signs
revealed the patient's temperature was 99 degrees Fahrenheit,
his blood pressure was 115/20, his heart rate was 65,
respiratory rate revealed intubated and Ambu bag ventilated,
and his oxygen saturation was 98%.   [**Location (un) 2611**] Coma Scale in
the Trauma Bay was 3.  Pupils were 3 mm and fixed.  The
oropharynx was clear.  The tympanic membranes were clear.
Cardiovascular examination revealed bradycardia at 40.  The
lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally.   Chest
revealed no deformities or tenderness.  The abdomen was soft,
nontender, and nondistended.  The pelvis was stable.  Flank
revealed no deformities.  No costovertebral angle tenderness.
Back revealed no deformities.  Cervical spine revealed no
deformities, stepoff, or tenderness.  Thoracolumbosacral
revealed no deformities, stepoff, or tenderness.  Rectal
examination was guaiac-negative.  Upper extremities revealed
no major deformities.  Positive ecchymosis over the left
elbow.  Right lower extremity revealed no deformities.  Left
lower extremity revealed positive external rotation of the
leg and shortening.  Pulse examination revealed 2+ radial,
femoral, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses.  No
palpable abdominal masses.

PERTINENT LABORATORY VALUES ON PRESENTATION:  Initial blood
gas was 7.48/22/380/17/4.  White blood cell count was 7.8,
his hematocrit was 31.3, and his platelets were 133.
Chemistry-7 revealed his sodium was 139, potassium was 3,
chloride was 116, blood urea nitrogen was 12, creatinine was
0.6, and his blood glucose was 140.  Coagulations revealed
his prothrombin time was 15.5, his partial thromboplastin
time was 33, and his INR was 1.6.  His amylase was 31.

PERTINENT RADIOLOGY/IMAGING:  Chest and pelvic x-rays were
within normal limits.

Cervical spine was within normal limits.

FAST was within normal limits.

A computed tomography of the head showed positive midbrain
and brain stem intraparenchymal bleed.

A computed tomography of the neck revealed no signs of
fractures.

A computed tomography of the abdomen revealed a grade 2
splenic laceration.

A computed tomography of the pelvis showed no fractures.

BRIEF SUMMARY OF HOSPITAL COURSE:   The patient was admitted
to the Trauma Intensive Care Unit for initial resuscitation.

Neurosurgery was consulted while Life Flight was en route.
They had decided that the patient would benefit from a
intraventricular drain.

The Orthopaedic Service was consulted and concluded that the
left femur fracture would require an open reduction/internal
fixation when the patient was stable.

Neurosurgery's initial recommendations were that the
patient's prognosis was grave and that there was very little
chance of a meaningful recovery.  During that time, the
patient's family was called numerous times.  The [**Hospital1 1559**]
Police Department was notified and assisted in finding the
next of [**Doctor First Name **].

During the patient's initial hospital stay, a central and
arterial line were placed.  The intraventricular drain was
placed by the Neurosurgery Service without complications.
The Orthopaedic Service placed the patient in Buck's traction
to extend the left lower extremity.

Vascular Surgery was consulted due to the patient's
unilateral ankle-brachial index of the lower extremities.
After Buck's traction was applied, the patient's
ankle-brachial index returned to 1.

On hospital day one, a family meeting was convened.  The
grave prognosis was relayed to the family.  Due to the grave
prognosis, it was decided that the patient's femur fracture
would not be addressed pending his disposition.

During the second hospital day, the patient's intracranial
pressure increased to 35.  The patient was given additional
doses of mannitol.  The repeat head computed tomography
showed worsening/blossoming of the brain stem and midbrain
intraparenchymal bleeds.  Neurosurgery concluded that this
was an unrecoverable injury.

These findings were relayed to the family during an in-depth
family meeting involving the Trauma Service, Intensive Care
Unit Service, and Neurosurgery Service.  During that time, it
was decided that the patient would be made do not
resuscitate/do not intubate but would continue full medical
support.

On hospital day three, the patient's intraparenchymal
pressures had increased regardless of the use of mannitol.
The patient's neurologic examination continued unchanged, as
the patient was unresponsive.

On hospital day three, the family decided that they would
make the patient comfort measures only and that the patient
should be an organ donor.

On [**1-1**], the patient was made comfort measures only.
He was started on a morphine drip for comfort.  The Organ
Bank was notified, and the Transplant Service was notified.
Early on [**1-1**], the patient expired and was an organ
donor.

CHIEF CAUSE OF DEATH:  Traumatic brain injury followed by a
cardiac death.
